title: Sun opposition Mercury
summary: Identity and viewpoint pull in opposite directions. What you intend to express may clash with how you’re processing information. The opportunity is to let feedback sharpen clarity instead of defaulting to defensiveness.

meaning.headline: Self-expression and thinking mirror each other from opposite sides.

frames.text: Sun–Mercury oppositions surface tension between personal stance and the facts or messages being received.
Communication can feel confrontational, but it also reveals blind spots if approached with curiosity.
You may notice a gap between the story you want to tell and the information available.
Debate can be productive when aimed at clarity rather than winning.
This aspect forces conflict or proves someone is wrong.

frictions: Taking disagreement as a personal attack
Speaking over others to defend a position
opportunities: Updating plans after receiving new data
Articulating boundaries without shutting down dialogue

do: Write down what you think you heard to test it.
Own your perspective without needing consensus.
Pause if conversation heat rises, then return deliberately.
avoid: Talking to win rather than to understand
Retreating into silence to avoid discomfort
Assuming tone over text or vice versa tells the whole story
Spreading unverified claims to back a point

reusable_lines.text: Let the tension between what you think and what you hear sharpen your clarity.
You can defend a point without defending your whole identity.

forbidden_claims: Declaring outcomes of arguments or negotiations
Assuming someone will be exposed as wrong
allowed_framing: Possibility language: can reveal gaps, can clarify
Agency-forward framing: you choose how to respond to disagreement
Contextual framing: conversations may feel charged, so pacing helps
